claim: Jon Voight once said "I pray all Americans who have seen and felt the meltdown of America with the Obama years, to please fight for Donald Trump
summarized_text: The agreement resolves over 95 percent of the 6,000 cases in which surgeons extracted the company’s Pinnacle implants because they left patients unable to walk and in pain, according to the report. The $1 billion total includes an earlier settlement for more than $400 million and there are still about 4,500 pending suits by patients with artificial hips that were not made totally of metal or haven’t been surgically removed, Bloomberg added. In February, Reuters reported J&J’s DePuy Orthopedics unit, which made the products, was in settlement talks to resolve most individual lawsuits alleging the company’s metal-on-metal Pinnacle hip implants were defective and caused severe injuries. The implants were said to cause a build-up of metal ions in the blood, causing groin pain, allergic reactions, bone erosion and tissue death. In 2013, DePuy ceased selling the metal-on-metal Pinnacle devices after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration strengthened its artificial hip regulations. The Pinnacle system continues to be sold with other material combinations. Texas-based plaintiff lawyer Mark Lanier, one of the main attorneys for the consumers, declined to comment. Johnson & Johnson did not immediately respond to Reuters’ request for comment.
label: true
explanation: Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay about $1 billion to resolve the bulk of lawsuits claiming the company sold defective metal-on-metal hip implants that ultimately had to be removed, Bloomberg reported on Tuesday, citing people with knowledge of the matter.
summarized_main_text: The agreement resolves over 95 percent of the 6,000 cases in which surgeons extracted the company’s Pinnacle implants because they left patients unable to walk and in pain, according to the report. The $1 billion total includes an earlier settlement for more than $400 million and there are still about 4,500 pending suits by patients with artificial hips that were not made totally of metal or haven’t been surgically removed, Bloomberg added. In February, Reuters reported J&J’s DePuy Orthopedics unit, which made the products, was in settlement talks to resolve most individual lawsuits alleging the company’s metal-on-metal Pinnacle hip implants were defective and caused severe injuries. The implants were said to cause a build-up of metal ions in the blood, causing groin pain, allergic reactions, bone erosion and tissue death. In 2013, DePuy ceased selling the metal-on-metal Pinnacle devices after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration strengthened its artificial hip regulations. The Pinnacle system continues to be sold with other material combinations. Texas-based plaintiff lawyer Mark Lanier, one of the main attorneys for the consumers, declined to comment. Johnson & Johnson did not immediately respond to Reuters’ request for comment.

### Task:
Using only the context provided, explain why the claim veracity is true.

### Input:
Context: Washington State Secretary of Health John Wiesman approved the county’s application Friday, making it the ninth county in the state to receive approval to move into phase two of the four-phase reopening process. Those counties can allow restaurants to open at 50% of capacity. Hair and nail salons, tattoo and makeup artists, and stores also can start reopening with additional protections in place. Counties applying for a quicker reopening must currently have a population of less than 75,000 and no new cases of COVID-19 in the last three weeks, among other stipulations, in order to be approved. The other eight counties of the 39 in Washington that can begin the second phase include: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens and Wahkiakum. Inslee and health officials have said other counties may enter phase two on June 1, depending on public-health COVID-19 data. Reopening businesses must comply with health and safety requirements outlined in their industry’s guidance, officials said. More than 17,950 people in Washington state have tested positive for the coronavirus and at least 992 have died. The virus causes mild to moderate symptoms in most patients, and the vast majority recover. But it is highly contagious and can cause severe illness and death in some patients, particularly the elderly and those with underlying health conditions.
Claim: Whitman County 9th county approved for phase 2 reopening.
The claim veracity: true

### Response:
Whitman County in Eastern Washington has been given the OK to take a faster path to reopening businesses, including restaurants, under Gov. Jay Inslee’s coronavirus recovery plan.

### Task:
Using only the context provided, explain why the claim veracity is false.

### Input:
Context: The article discusses a political ad by Rick Barber, a tea party enthusiast running for Congress in Alabama's Second District Republican run-off. The ad features Barber having a fictitious conversation with three Founding Fathers, where he rails against the IRS and the health care bill. The article examines Barber's claims in the ad and fact-checks them. One claim made by Barber in the ad is that "without representation, the IRS can increase taxes." The article points out that the IRS does not have the authority to increase taxes, as that power lies with Congress. The Constitution states that Congress has the power to lay and collect taxes. Barber argues that he meant the lack of proper representation in Washington, but the article finds this explanation disingenuous. Another claim made by Barber is that the IRS is going to force people to buy health insurance. The article clarifies that it was Congress, not the IRS, that passed the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, which establishes a penalty for those who choose not to have insurance. The IRS would enforce the tax penalties, but it would be incorrect to say that the IRS is requiring people to buy insurance. The article also addresses Barber's comment about the Founding Fathers revolting against a tea tax. A history professor explains that the issues that led to the American Revolution were more complex than just the tax on tea. The Americans were concerned about being taxed without their consent and not being represented in Parliament. Overall, the article concludes that Barber's claims in the ad are incorrect. The IRS does not have the power to increase taxes without representation, and it is Congress that passed the health care bill, not the IRS. The article suggests that the Founding Fathers would not appreciate being misled and rules Barber's statement as false.
Claim: Without representation, (the IRS) can increase taxes.
The claim veracity: false

### Response:
"Alabama Congressional candidate Rick Barber's ""Gather your armies"" ad goes viral"

claim: NFL players protesting police brutality are doing so because they have many children with different women, leading their families into lives of crime.
summarized_text: The article discusses a Facebook post that falsely claims that NFL players who protest police brutality by kneeling during the national anthem have many children with different women, which leads their families into lives of crime. The post specifically mentions retired players Antonio Cromartie, Travis Henry, Willis McGahee, Derrick Thomas, Bennie Blades, Ray Lewis, and Marshall Faulk, and highlights the number of children they have with multiple women. However, the post's premise that growing up in a single-parent household predicts criminal activity is false. According to a 2003 study by the Center for Law and Social Policy, children who grow up in families with both their biological parents in a low-conflict marriage tend to fare better in various aspects compared to children in single-parent or cohabiting-parent households. However, it is important to note that most children not living with married, biological parents still grow up without serious problems. The article also mentions that violent crime rates have significantly decreased over the years, while the decline of marriage has continued. This challenges the theory that family breakdown drives crime rates. The argument that growing up in a single-parent household leads to criminal behavior is therefore questionable. Furthermore, none of the players mentioned in the Facebook post are currently active in the NFL. Terricka Cromartie, Antonio Cromartie's wife, claimed in an Instagram post that her husband's employment was terminated because he kneeled during the national anthem, similar to Colin Kaepernick. However, Faulk, who is currently an analyst for the NFL Network, has expressed support for Kaepernick's protests, emphasizing that it is about holding someone accountable for lives being lost, particularly among black people. In conclusion, the claim made in the Facebook post that NFL players protest police brutality because they have many children with different women, leading their families into lives of crime, is false. The post misrepresents the players' intentions and falsely links single-parent households to criminal behavior.
label: false
explanation: Lewis, who is an NFL analyst for Showtime, said in September 2017 that the Baltimore Ravens (his former team) almost signed Kaepernick to a contract, but were put off after the quarterback’s girlfriend posted a picture of Lewis and Steve Bisciotti juxtaposed with a still from the movie Django Unchained showing Samuel L. Jackson’s slave character mourning his owner.

claim: From 1947 to 1979, family incomes for rich, middle-income and poor Americans grew about the same rate. But since 1979, incomes for rich families have grown much faster.
summarized_text: Dovato, a combination of dolutegravir and lamivudine, was approved in the United States in April for newly-diagnosed patients, boosting the British drugmaker’s prospects against Gilead Sciences Inc, which currently leads the HIV treatment market. Liberium analyst Graham Doyle said the study results will add to the data package supporting Dovato as GSK aims to convince doctors that two drug therapies are just as effective as triple therapies. GSK is betting that a shift to using two drugs rather than three will boost its sales by offering patients a therapy with fewer potentially toxic side effects. The study evaluated the effectiveness of Dovato, a combination of dolutegravir and lamivudine, in adults with the HIV-1 virus who switched to the regimen from at least a triple combination containing Gilead Sciences’ Descovy, the British company’s HIV drugs division ViiV said. ViiV also said adults who used Dovato did not develop any resistance to the treatment. GSK already has a two-drug regimen Juluca on the market, but only for HIV patients that have received prior treatment. Pfizer Inc and Shionogi & Co Ltd also have small stakes in ViiV, which accounted for about 39% of GSK’s group operating profit last year, according to UBS analysts. The HIV-1 category has the most widespread strains of the virus, which severely affects the body’s immune system.
label: true
explanation: GlaxoSmithKline Plc’s two-drug HIV regimen Dovato was successful in suppressing the AIDS-causing virus in patients over 48 weeks at the same level of a previous three-drug treatment in a late-stage trial, the drugmaker said on Wednesday.
summarized_main_text: Dovato, a combination of dolutegravir and lamivudine, was approved in the United States in April for newly-diagnosed patients, boosting the British drugmaker’s prospects against Gilead Sciences Inc, which currently leads the HIV treatment market. Liberium analyst Graham Doyle said the study results will add to the data package supporting Dovato as GSK aims to convince doctors that two drug therapies are just as effective as triple therapies. GSK is betting that a shift to using two drugs rather than three will boost its sales by offering patients a therapy with fewer potentially toxic side effects. The study evaluated the effectiveness of Dovato, a combination of dolutegravir and lamivudine, in adults with the HIV-1 virus who switched to the regimen from at least a triple combination containing Gilead Sciences’ Descovy, the British company’s HIV drugs division ViiV said. ViiV also said adults who used Dovato did not develop any resistance to the treatment. GSK already has a two-drug regimen Juluca on the market, but only for HIV patients that have received prior treatment. Pfizer Inc and Shionogi & Co Ltd also have small stakes in ViiV, which accounted for about 39% of GSK’s group operating profit last year, according to UBS analysts. The HIV-1 category has the most widespread strains of the virus, which severely affects the body’s immune system.

claim: Hank Johnson Says "by reducing chronic health care costs in the State of Georgia, we can reduce the $32.8 billion lost each year due to lack of productivity and economic costs.
summarized_text: Georgia Congressman Hank Johnson claims that by reducing chronic health care costs in the state, the $32.8 billion lost each year due to lack of productivity and economic costs can also be reduced. Johnson's claim is based on a study done by the Milken Institute in 2007, which found that more than half of Americans suffer from one or more chronic diseases. The study focused on seven diseases, including cancer, diabetes, heart disease, hypertension, mental disorder, pulmonary conditions, and strokes. In Georgia, the economic impact of these diseases was estimated to be $32.8 billion. The researchers calculated the number of lost workdays by using data from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's National Health Interview Survey and multiplying those days lost by wages per employee. Georgia's total was 3 percent of the national cost, which is proportional to the state's population. The lead researcher of the study, Ross DeVol, stated that the number is likely higher today. However, another report released by Gallup-Healthways in May estimated the total lost productivity from various health problems to be $84 billion a year. This report included chronic conditions such as asthma, cancer, depression, diabetes, heart attacks, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, obesity, and physical pains. The estimated cost per worker per day was $341. The Gallup-Healthways report was based on interviews with 94,000 adults nationwide who worked more than 30 hours a week. The majority reported missing about one day every three months due to poor health. Johnson's claim is based on accurate information from the Milken Institute study, but there are differing estimates from other research. ### Task:
Using only the context provided, explain why the claim veracity is true.

### Input:
Context: Washington State Secretary of Health John Wiesman approved the county’s application Friday, making it the ninth county in the state to receive approval to move into phase two of the four-phase reopening process. Those counties can allow restaurants to open at 50% of capacity. Hair and nail salons, tattoo and makeup artists, and stores also can start reopening with additional protections in place. Counties applying for a quicker reopening must currently have a population of less than 75,000 and no new cases of COVID-19 in the last three weeks, among other stipulations, in order to be approved. The other eight counties of the 39 in Washington that can begin the second phase include: Columbia, Ferry, Garfield, Lincoln, Pend Oreille, Skamania, Stevens and Wahkiakum. Inslee and health officials have said other counties may enter phase two on June 1, depending on public-health COVID-19 data. Reopening businesses must comply with health and safety requirements outlined in their industry’s guidance, officials said. More than 17,950 people in Washington state have tested positive for the coronavirus and at least 992 have died. The virus causes mild to moderate symptoms in most patients, and the vast majority recover. But it is highly contagious and can cause severe illness and death in some patients, particularly the elderly and those with underlying health conditions.
Claim: Whitman County 9th county approved for phase 2 reopening.
The claim veracity: true

### Response:
Whitman County in Eastern Washington has been given the OK to take a faster path to reopening businesses, including restaurants, under Gov. Jay Inslee’s coronavirus recovery plan.

The IRS would enforce the tax penalties, but it would be incorrect to say that the IRS is requiring people to buy insurance. A history professor explains that the issues that led to the American Revolution were more complex than just the tax on tea. The Americans were concerned about being taxed without their consent and not being represented in Parliament. Overall, the article concludes that Barber's claims in the ad are incorrect. The IRS does not have the power to increase taxes without representation, and it is Congress that passed the health care bill, not the IRS. The article suggests that the Founding Fathers would not appreciate being misled and rules Barber's statement as false.
Claim: Without representation, (the IRS) can increase taxes.
The claim veracity: false

"Alabama Congressional candidate Rick Barber's ""Gather your armies"" ad goes viral"

claim: Earthquake in Turkey-Iran border region kills nine, injures more than 100.
summarized_text: A powerful earthquake struck the Turkey-Iran border region, resulting in the deaths of nine people and injuring over 100 others. Three of the deceased were children, and nine individuals are in critical condition. The quake caused over 1,000 buildings to collapse in Turkey, leading to a rescue effort to find those trapped under the rubble. The tremor also damaged buildings in the Turkish city of Van and several villages in Iran. In Iran, 75 people were injured, with six requiring hospitalization. Following the initial earthquake, there were several aftershocks, including a larger tremor measuring 6.0 magnitude. No immediate reports of damage or casualties were received from the subsequent quake. Both Iran and Turkey are prone to earthquakes due to their location on major fault lines. Turkish TV footage showed people using shovels and their hands to dig through the rubble, while damaged buildings, fallen roofs, and cracked walls were observed in various villages. The governor of Van confirmed the loss of life and widespread destruction in the affected areas. The earthquake had a depth of 5 km and struck at 8:53 a.m. The second significant quake occurred at 7:00 p.m. Dozens of villages in Turkey were rattled, and nearly 150 tents were sent to provide shelter for affected families. The Turkish Disaster and Emergency Management Authority initiated rescue operations in villages near the epicenter. The U.S. Geological Survey reported the epicenter to be 47 km west of the Iranian city of Khoy. Last month, another earthquake in eastern Turkey caused over 40 fatalities, while an earthquake in Iran caused structural damage to homes without resulting in any deaths. Rescue teams have been dispatched to the affected area in Iran's West Azarbaijan province, where several towns and villages suffered significant damage.
label: true
explanation: Nine people were killed and buildings collapsed across southeastern Turkey on Sunday when a magnitude 5.7 earthquake struck near the border with Iran, injuring more than a hundred in villages and towns in both countries, government officials said.

claim: Botox use on migraines gains support
summarized_text: A recent study on the use of Botox for migraines has gained support, although it does not mention the costs of the injections or whether insurance would cover it. The study found that while Botox did not significantly reduce the number of headache episodes, it did reduce the number of days patients suffered from headaches. However, the study did not provide specific data on the difference. The article provides a balanced tone by framing the results as being greeted with reactions ranging from "exuberance to caution." It does not mention any potential harms of Botox injections, although there are risks associated with the procedure. Consumers should seek out a skilled and experienced practitioner for the injections. The article also highlights the challenge of measuring headache duration or severity and mentions that the details of the study have not been released. It accurately states that chronic, severe migraines are the indication in question, not everyday headaches. The article quotes multiple experts who provide valuable perspective. It does not mention alternative treatments for migraines, but it does mention that Botox is available and FDA-approved for several other indications. The article concludes by stating that the reader can assume the story did not rely solely on a press release as the source of information.
label: true
explanation: Botox, or Botulinum Toxin Type A is typically regarded as a way to reduce fine lines and wrinkles. However, it is increasingly being used to treat disorders related to overactive muscles and twiching because of the temporary muscle paralysis that Botox causes. This story reports on a news release by Allergan, the manufacturer of Botox, about the results of a new study looking at Botox as a preventive measure for chronic migraine sufferers. This story does a commendable job outlining the evidence to support Botox use for this indication. It rightly points out that there are serious questions about the methodology and that the details of the study have not been made available. Furthermore, it accurately describes the availability and novelty of Botox and is careful to quote multiple, independent experts who provide valuable perspective. The story could have been improved by describing the costs of Botox injections, and mentioning possible harms or side effects and the alternative treatment options, of which there are many. Overall, a very well balanced and informative piece that could have easily gotten off course.

claim: Trump administration drops Obama-era water protection rule.
summarized_text: The Trump administration has repealed an Obama-era rule that defined the waterways subject to federal regulation. The 2015 Waters of the United States rule aimed to clarify which waterways were protected under the Clean Water Act. Environmental groups criticized the move, arguing that it would lead to less safe drinking water and damage to wetlands that prevent flooding and provide habitat for wildlife. The administration plans to adopt a new rule by the end of the year that is expected to define protected waterways more narrowly than the Obama policy. The Clean Water Act requires landowners to obtain federal permits before developing or polluting navigable waterways, but disputes have long persisted over what other waters are subject to regulation. The Obama rule provided federal oversight to upstream tributaries and headwaters, including wetlands, ponds, lakes, and streams that can affect the quality of navigable waters. The Trump administration's action is seen as a rollback of environmental protections put into place under President Obama. Environmentalists argue that the repeal is a victory for land developers, oil and gas drillers, and miners who will exploit the ambiguity to dredge and fill small streams and wetlands. The Natural Resources Defense Council said the administration's action would be challenged in court. The American Farm Bureau Federation, on the other hand, welcomed the repeal, stating that the 2015 rule had generated a greater sense of urgency among its membership than any other issue. The question of which waters are covered under the Clean Water Act has inspired decades of lawsuits and numerous bills in Congress. The Supreme Court in 2006 produced three differing opinions on the matter, leading the Obama administration to craft its rule.
label: true
explanation: The Trump administration on Thursday revoked an Obama-era regulation that shielded many U.S. wetlands and streams from pollution but was opposed by developers and farmers who said it hurt economic development and infringed on property rights.
summarized_main_text: The Trump administration has repealed an Obama-era rule that defined the waterways subject to federal regulation. The 2015 Waters of the United States rule aimed to clarify which waterways were protected under the Clean Water Act. Environmental groups criticized the move, arguing that it would lead to less safe drinking water and damage to wetlands that prevent flooding and provide habitat for wildlife. The administration plans to adopt a new rule by the end of the year that is expected to define protected waterways more narrowly than the Obama policy. The Clean Water Act requires landowners to obtain federal permits before developing or polluting navigable waterways, but disputes have long persisted over what other waters are subject to regulation. The Obama rule provided federal oversight to upstream tributaries and headwaters, including wetlands, ponds, lakes, and streams that can affect the quality of navigable waters. The Trump administration's action is seen as a rollback of environmental protections put into place under President Obama. Environmentalists argue that the repeal is a victory for land developers, oil and gas drillers, and miners who will exploit the ambiguity to dredge and fill small streams and wetlands. The Natural Resources Defense Council said the administration's action would be challenged in court. The American Farm Bureau Federation, on the other hand, welcomed the repeal, stating that the 2015 rule had generated a greater sense of urgency among its membership than any other issue. The question of which waters are covered under the Clean Water Act has inspired decades of lawsuits and numerous bills in Congress. The Supreme Court in 2006 produced three differing opinions on the matter, leading the Obama administration to craft its rule.

claim: John Bel Edwards Says of the coronavirus threat, “there was not a single suggestion by anyone, a doctor, a scientist, a political figure, that we needed to cancel Mardi Gras.”
summarized_text: Louisiana Governor John Bel Edwards stated that there were no suggestions from doctors, scientists, or political figures to cancel Mardi Gras celebrations in light of the coronavirus pandemic. This claim was fact-checked by PolitiFact, who reviewed statements from President Donald Trump and guidance from federal and state health agencies. They found that there were no suggestions to cancel large public events like Mardi Gras before February 25, when the biggest parades took place. In January and most of February, U.S. officials stated that the coronavirus risk to the American public was low and that there was no community spread of the virus. On February 26, the day after Mardi Gras, a Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) doctor mentioned that the situation was rapidly evolving and the virus was spreading worldwide. However, there were still only a few cases in the United States and no reports of community spread at that time. The earliest suggestion from a federal agency that large events may need to be canceled came on February 26, after Mardi Gras celebrations. On February 29, a health official from Washington state mentioned that if they started to see more spread in Washington, they might consider recommending measures like canceling large public events. The first presumptive case of coronavirus in Louisiana was reported on March 9, and on March 13, Governor Edwards signed a proclamation to stop gatherings of more than 250 people and close all K-12 public schools statewide. Based on models created in mid-March, it is assumed that infections silently spread during crowded Mardi Gras parades. Epidemiologists from nearby states began reporting confirmed cases of coronavirus in people who had traveled to New Orleans for the festivities. However, at the time of the parades, it was not known that the virus was in the state. In summary, Governor Edwards' claim that there were no suggestions to cancel Mardi Gras from doctors, scientists, or political figures is accurate. PolitiFact reviewed public comments and found no suggestions to cancel large public events before February 25, when Mardi Gras celebrations took place.
label: true
explanation: The Carnival season in New Orleans kicked off early January and ended Feb. 25. There were few coronavirus cases in the United States at the time, and health officials then said there was no community spread. The earliest indication we found from a federal agency saying that large events may need to be canceled came Feb. 26, after Mardi Gras celebrations.

claim: The Trump Administration’s policies have halted a research effort seeking a cure for HIV.
summarized_text: The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) canceled a contract with Advanced Bioscience Resources Inc. (ABR) to procure fetal tissue for federal medical research projects. HHS claimed that the contract did not have appropriate protections and did not meet procurement requirements. As a result, HHS announced a comprehensive review of all research involving fetal tissue, effectively pausing all research that relied on fetal tissue. ABR supplied fetal tissue to two National Institutes of Health (NIH) laboratories, one of which used the tissue to create humanized mice for testing the efficacy of immunotherapeutic drugs, particularly for HIV drug testing. The director of the Gladstone Center for HIV Cure Research in San Francisco collaborated with one of the NIH laboratories and stated that the ban on fetal tissue procurement stopped their line of investigation as they needed multiple experiments to reach scientific conclusions. HHS acknowledged that they temporarily blocked staff scientists from procuring fetal tissue but claimed they did not think it would affect the study in question. However, the director of the Gladstone Center for HIV Cure Research stated that they were never made aware that they should inform the NIH of their need for more fetal tissue. The Trump administration's policies on fetal tissue research were seen by many as a proxy debate over abortion. Anti-abortion groups campaigned for the government to cancel its contract with ABR, which led to the cancellation of the contract and the pause on fetal tissue research. The director of the Gladstone Center for HIV Cure Research believes that this change reflects a new political situation in Washington, D.C. and is impacting their science. The article concludes that the Trump administration's policies have halted a research effort seeking a cure for HIV.
label: true
explanation: Greene told us that after much internal debate, he and Hasenkrug plan on running that initial experiment anyway, with the hopes that the political climate will change in their favor come January 2019.

summarized_text: The Rhode Island Democrat says the state should expect to get nearly $2.3 million of that funding this year from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Reed says the federal money will be used to improve immunization levels and help eliminate vaccine-preventable diseases among children in Rhode Island. The funding can be used so that health care providers can vaccinate uninsured children, underinsured children and children on Medicaid at no cost to their family. Reed says Rhode Island isn’t immune from the threat of a measles outbreak, but its high vaccination rate of young people is the best line of defense.

claim: Drug critic slams FDA over antibiotic oversight in meat production.
summarized_text: The Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC), a non-governmental group that criticizes the use of drugs in the meat industry, has conducted a study that raises concerns over the use of antibiotics in meat production. The study found that the FDA did not take action to remove 30 antibiotic-based livestock feed products from the market, even after federal investigators determined that many of these antibiotics did not meet current regulatory standards for protecting human health. The FDA had previously unveiled guidelines for drug makers and agricultural companies to voluntarily phase out antibiotic use as a growth enhancer in livestock, in an effort to combat the surge in human resistance to certain antibiotics. However, the NRDC's study suggests that the FDA has not effectively enforced these guidelines. The NRDC's study focused on a review conducted by the FDA from 2001 to 2010, which examined 30 penicillin and tetracycline-based antibiotic feed additives that had been approved for use in livestock and poultry to promote growth. The study found evidence to suggest that nine of these drugs are still on the market and used by livestock producers. One of the drugs still on the market is Zoetis Inc's Penicillin G Procaine 50/100, which is fed to poultry to aid in weight gain. The NRDC claims that the FDA twice expressed concerns to Zoetis about the drug failing to meet safety regulations. Some academics specializing in antibiotic resistance have criticized the NRDC's study, arguing that it does not reflect current regulatory standards as some of the drugs have been withdrawn from the market and the study assessed outdated FDA safety guidelines. However, the NRDC argues that its findings raise questions about the effectiveness of regulators in enforcing the new guidelines. The FDA has stated that it began reviewing older, approved penicillin and tetracycline products in 2001 and issued letters to companies asking for additional safety data. The agency claims to have employed a strategy to address concerns about the production use of medically important antimicrobials in food-producing animals. The FDA believes that its current strategy is the most efficient and effective way to change the use of these products in animal agriculture. Overall, the NRDC's study highlights concerns over the FDA's oversight of antibiotic use in meat production and raises questions about the effectiveness of the agency's guidelines and enforcement.
label: true
explanation: The United States Food and Drug Administration allowed 18 animal drugs to stay on the market even after an agency review found the drugs posed a “high risk” of exposing humans to antibiotic-resistant bacteria through food supply, according to a study released Monday by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

claim: Study challenges health benefits of moderate drinking.
summarized_text: A study conducted in China challenges the belief that moderate drinking has health benefits. The researchers found that moderate drinking slightly increases the risk of stroke and high blood pressure. However, they were unable to determine if small amounts of alcohol also increase the chances of a heart attack. The study tracked over 500,000 people in China for a decade and recorded their medical history, including their alcohol consumption. The researchers took genetics into account by focusing on two variants common among East Asians that can make drinking unpleasant. For those with the variants, drinking alcohol can result in symptoms such as turning red, a fast heart rate, nausea, or headaches. The researchers found that alcohol increases the risk of stroke by about one-third for every four additional drinks per day. They also found no protective effects for moderate drinking. People who drink up to two drinks a day, which qualifies as moderate drinking, have an increased stroke risk of about 10% to 15% compared to nondrinkers. However, there were not enough heart attacks among the participants to draw a conclusion about heart risks. The study's senior author, Richard Peto of the University of Oxford, stated that the claims of alcohol having a protective effect have no serious scientific basis. He also mentioned that the findings should apply to other populations beyond China and to any alcoholic drinks, even though the study participants mostly drank spirits. In a journal commentary, the authors of the study called for stricter controls on alcohol, stating that its risks have been underestimated. They compared the alcohol industry to the tobacco industry and suggested that it should be regulated similarly. Overall, the study challenges the belief that moderate drinking has health benefits and suggests that the risks of alcohol have been underestimated.
label: true
explanation: It might just be enough to kill your buzz: A new study challenges the idea that a drink or two a day could actually be good for you.
summarized_main_text: A study conducted in China challenges the belief that moderate drinking has health benefits. The researchers found that moderate drinking slightly increases the risk of stroke and high blood pressure. The study's senior author, Richard Peto of the University of Oxford, stated that the claims of alcohol having a protective effect have no serious scientific basis. He also mentioned that the findings should apply to other populations beyond China and to any alcoholic drinks, even though the study participants mostly drank spirits. In a journal commentary, the authors of the study called for stricter controls on alcohol, stating that its risks have been underestimated. They compared the alcohol industry to the tobacco industry and suggested that it should be regulated similarly. Overall, the study challenges the belief that moderate drinking has health benefits and suggests that the risks of alcohol have been underestimated.

claim: At least seven missing in Alabama after deadly weekend tornadoes.
summarized_text: The tiny community of Beauregard, near the Alabama-Georgia border, is mourning the loss of 23 people who were killed by tornadoes over the weekend. The victims ranged in age from 6 to 93 years old, and included four children and seven people from one family. Most of the deceased were found near their homes. Search crews have narrowed their focus to the most affected areas and hope to transition from a search and rescue effort to a recovery effort soon. U.S. President Donald Trump has announced plans to visit the devastated areas on Friday. The tornadoes, caused by a late-winter "supercell" thunderstorm, had winds of 170 mph and caused significant damage to mobile homes and trees. The Beauregard community may have had as little as eight or nine minutes to seek shelter after the warning was issued. In addition to the 23 confirmed deaths, over 50 people were reported injured, making this the deadliest tornado outbreak since 2013.
label: true

claim: COVID-19 started because we eat animals.
summarized_text: The claim that "COVID-19 started because we eat animals" is not supported by evidence. The article explains that early on in the pandemic, there were baseless claims linking the disease to the consumption of bats in China. The Instagram post from the account for "Cowspiracy" piggybacks on this misinformation. It refers to a vegan activist's post that cites the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the World Health Organization (WHO) to support the claim that meat consumption caused the COVID-19 outbreak. However, neither statement from the CDC nor the WHO supports the link between COVID-19 and meat-eating. Scientists are still investigating the source of COVID-19, but there is no evidence that it started because of meat consumption. The CDC states that most new or emerging infectious diseases in people come from animals, but this does not specifically link COVID-19 to meat-eating. COVID-19 is a betacoronavirus similar to MERS and SARS, and all three originate in bats. The recent outbreak suggests a likely single, recent emergence of the virus from an animal reservoir. While early cases in Wuhan, China, had connections to a seafood and live-animal market, later cases had no connection to the market, indicating person-to-person spread. Studies suggest that intermediate hosts are needed for the disease to spread from bats to humans, but meat consumption is not necessarily part of the equation. For example, the Ebola outbreak was initially thought to be linked to the consumption of bat meat, but it was later discovered that patient zero was likely infected through bat droppings. MERS was primarily spread through contact with live camels rather than camel meat. Recent studies suggest that pangolins could be an intermediate host for COVID-19, but conclusive proof has not been found. Pangolins are sought-after in China for their meat and scales, despite a worldwide ban. However, there is currently no evidence that eating meat is the source of the COVID-19 pandemic. In summary, the claim that "COVID-19 started because we eat animals" is not supported by scientific evidence. While the virus likely originated from bats, there is no direct link between meat consumption and the outbreak. The Instagram post mentioned in the claim ignores critical facts and misrepresents the information from the CDC and WHO.
label: false
explanation: The CDC and WHO say that emerging infectious diseases in humans frequently come from animals. Scientists think COVID-19 originated in bats and then jumped to another animal host, possibly pangolins, before spreading to humans. As of now, there is no evidence that eating meat is the source of the coronavirus outbreak.

claim: Allen West Says the coronavirus has a “99.9% recovery rate” in Texas.
summarized_text: Retired Army Lt. Col. Allen West, the newly elected chairman of the Texas Republican Party, claimed that the recovery rate for COVID-19 in Texas is 99.9%. However, this claim is inaccurate. At the time of West's statement on July 27, Texas had reported 385,923 positive COVID-19 cases and 5,713 deaths. The state has since corrected the number of fatalities for that day to 5,489. West's numbers for positive cases and deaths are outdated, and his calculation for the recovery rate is incorrect. West's calculation of the recovery rate involved dividing the number of people in Texas who did not die after testing positive for COVID-19 by the entire population of Texas. However, this method is flawed. Calculating the recovery rate should involve counting the number of people who have been infected with COVID-19 and the number of those who have recovered. The latest numbers would put the recovery rate closer to 98.7%. Furthermore, West's definition of recovery as all those who tested positive and did not die is one way to describe it, but it may not be the most accurate. Research has shown that "recovered" patients can still have impaired organ function and abnormal blood test results even after they are no longer infectious. Doctors and researchers have raised concerns about the long-term impact of COVID-19. Different states use distinct formulas to calculate the recovery rate, and it has been a point of friction for some public officials. In Texas, the state produces an estimate based on hospitalizations and average stays. West's claim of a 99.9% recovery rate could be misleading and dangerous, as it may give people a false impression that most infected individuals return to their previous state of health. This could lead to a decrease in efforts to stop the spread of the virus. In conclusion, West's claim of a 99.9% recovery rate for COVID-19 in Texas is inaccurate. His numbers for positive cases and deaths are outdated, and his calculation for the recovery rate is flawed. Even if all people who were infected and did not die were considered as having recovered, the rate would be 98.7%. However, this definition of recovery is misleading, as studies have shown that many individuals experience long-term health effects from the virus.
label: false
explanation: The calculation behind West’s “recovery rate” is not accurate. He looked at people who did not die after contracting COVID-19 and compared that figure to the entire population, not just those individuals who have been infected. Experts said his definition of the recovery rate is also misleading, as it counts any person who did not die as having recovered. In reality, studies have shown lasting health impacts on those who contracted the virus but are no longer infectious.
summarized_main_text:
Retired Army Lt. Col. Allen West, the newly elected chairman of the Texas Republican Party, claimed that the recovery rate for COVID-19 in Texas is 99.9%. However, this claim is inaccurate. At the time of West's statement on July 27, Texas had reported 385,923 positive COVID-19 cases and 5,713 deaths. The state has since corrected the number of fatalities for that day to 5,489. West's numbers for positive cases and deaths are outdated, and his calculation for the recovery rate is incorrect.

West's calculation of the recovery rate involved dividing the number of people in Texas who did not die after testing positive for COVID-19 by the entire population of Texas. However, this method is flawed. Calculating the recovery rate should involve counting the number of people who have been infected with COVID-19 and the number of those who have recovered. The latest numbers would put the recovery rate closer to 98.7%.

Furthermore, West's definition of recovery as all those who tested positive and did not die is one way to describe it, but it may not be the most accurate. Research has shown that "recovered" patients can still have impaired organ function and abnormal blood test results even after they are no longer infectious. Doctors and researchers have raised concerns about the long-term impact of COVID-19.

Different states use distinct formulas to calculate the recovery rate, and it has been a point of friction for some public officials. In Texas, the state produces an estimate based on hospitalizations and average stays. West's claim of a 99.9% recovery rate could be misleading and dangerous, as it may give people a false impression that most infected individuals return to their previous state of health. This could lead to a decrease in efforts to stop the spread of the virus.

In conclusion, West's claim of a 99.9% recovery rate for COVID-19 in Texas is inaccurate. His numbers for positive cases and deaths are outdated, and his calculation for the recovery rate is flawed. Even if all people who were infected and did not die were considered as having recovered, the rate would be 98.7%. However, this definition of recovery is misleading, as studies have shown that many individuals experience long-term health effects from the virus.

claim: Prostate Cancer Drug Gets Lukewarm Review
summarized_text: The article discusses the lukewarm review of the prostate cancer drug, Provenge. It mentions that the treatment costs $93,000 per patient, but fails to provide context by comparing it to alternative treatments. An editorial in the New England Journal of Medicine states that alternative treatments cost $1,800 per patient. The article also mentions that in clinical trials, Provenge extended the lives of certain men with advanced prostate cancer by about four months. However, it fails to mention that expert reviewers who analyzed the evidence for Medicare found the actual quantity of the benefit to be "less certain" due to weaknesses in the trials. This raises questions about the accuracy of the "four months" additional survival estimate. Furthermore, the article does not mention the potential harms associated with Provenge. Clinical trials reported infusion reactions, infections, and the FDA ordered further study of strokes in people who receive Provenge. The article also fails to adequately explain the shortcomings identified by expert reviewers in the trial design of Provenge. The reviewers rated the quality of evidence on survival as only "fair" and recommended further trials to provide more reliable estimates of the effects of Provenge. The article does not mention the differences in disease progression time between patients receiving Provenge and those in the control group, nor does it address the potential interactions between Provenge and other treatments. Although the article mentions that Provenge is approved for patients with advanced prostate cancer resistant to hormone-deprivation therapy, it does not include an independent source addressing the scientific issues raised by the Medicare analysis. Additionally, the article does not disclose that the cancer advocacy group cited in the article receives support from and promotes its services to health care corporations, including pharmaceutical companies. The article also fails to mention other treatment approaches for advanced prostate cancer, despite the Medicare analysis highlighting questions about the influence of other treatments, including chemotherapy, on the outcomes of Provenge trials. In conclusion, the article provides a lukewarm review of Provenge but lacks important context, fails to address potential harms, and does not adequately explain the shortcomings identified by expert reviewers. It also lacks independent sources and does not mention alternative treatment approaches.
label: mixture
explanation: This story reports on an analysis done for the agency that oversees Medicare of the evidence of the effects of Provenge (sipuleucel-T) in certain men with advanced prostate cancer. It summarizes some of the conclusions and includes comments about how the analysis might influence a decision about whether Medicare and Medicaid will pay for the expensive new treatment. But the story leaves readers with the impression that the drug has been proven to extend the life of the average patient by about four months when actually there are many uncertainties about that estimate due to weaknesses in the clinical trials sponsored by the maker of the Provenge. The assessment done for Medicare underscores the questions that still need to be answered in order for doctors and patients to know whether and how to use Provenge, but that perspective is largely missing from this story. This story portrays debates about insurance coverage of Provenge as a matter of how much value to place on four months of life. But what the federal analysis of the Provenge trials actually focuses on is uncertainty about the amount of additional survival and questions about how other factors besides Provenge (including other treatments that were given to the trial participants) might have affected the trial results. Prostate cancer is the most common cancer occurring in men, though most tumors grow slowly and men diagnosed with the disease typically die of something other than their prostate cancer. Some tumors are aggressive and more effective treatments are needed for these cases. Provenge’s novel immunotherapy approach offers an attractive alternative to existing treatments, but the initial application for FDA approval was rejected in 2007. A new clinical trial was done and the treatment was approved for sale in the U.S. earlier this year. Although historically Medicare and Medicaid have covered treatments deemed safe and effective without considering the magnitude of the expected benefit, the limited additional survival and the high cost of Provenge treatment have highlighted debates about whether and how to consider these factors in deciding whether a particular treatment should be reimbursed.
summarized_main_text:
The article discusses the lukewarm review of the prostate cancer drug, Provenge. It mentions that the treatment costs $93,000 per patient, but fails to provide context by comparing it to alternative treatments. An editorial in the New England Journal of Medicine states that alternative treatments cost $1,800 per patient.

The article also mentions that in clinical trials, Provenge extended the lives of certain men with advanced prostate cancer by about four months. However, it fails to mention that expert reviewers who analyzed the evidence for Medicare found the actual quantity of the benefit to be "less certain" due to weaknesses in the trials. This raises questions about the accuracy of the "four months" additional survival estimate.

Furthermore, the article does not mention the potential harms associated with Provenge. Clinical trials reported infusion reactions, infections, and the FDA ordered further study of strokes in people who receive Provenge.

The article also fails to adequately explain the shortcomings identified by expert reviewers in the trial design of Provenge. The reviewers rated the quality of evidence on survival as only "fair" and recommended further trials to provide more reliable estimates of the effects of Provenge. The article does not mention the differences in disease progression time between patients receiving Provenge and those in the control group, nor does it address the potential interactions between Provenge and other treatments.

Although the article mentions that Provenge is approved for patients with advanced prostate cancer resistant to hormone-deprivation therapy, it does not include an independent source addressing the scientific issues raised by the Medicare analysis. Additionally, the article does not disclose that the cancer advocacy group cited in the article receives support from and promotes its services to health care corporations, including pharmaceutical companies.

The article also fails to mention other treatment approaches for advanced prostate cancer, despite the Medicare analysis highlighting questions about the influence of other treatments, including chemotherapy, on the outcomes of Provenge trials.

In conclusion, the article provides a lukewarm review of Provenge but lacks important context, fails to address potential harms, and does not adequately explain the shortcomings identified by expert reviewers. It also lacks independent sources and does not mention alternative treatment approaches.

claim: Minnesota environmentalists aren’t excited about DFL’s wins.
summarized_text: Environmental organizations in Minnesota are not optimistic about the future of two controversial natural resource projects in the state: PolyMet's proposed copper-nickel mine and the plan to replace an aging Enbridge oil pipeline. Despite supporting many other causes championed by environmentalists, it is unlikely that the newly elected DFLer Tim Walz, who succeeded Governor Mark Dayton, will significantly change course on these projects. The PolyMet project recently received key environmental permits from the Department of Natural Resources, a decision celebrated by those who see it as a source of jobs. However, environmentalists are concerned about the potential pollution of Lake Superior and the surrounding watershed. Governor Dayton has opposed the Enbridge project, and his Department of Commerce has been vocal in its opposition. Although he vetoed a bill that would have authorized the pipeline to move forward without typical approval, the Public Utilities Commission approved the project in June. Walz, as governor, will not have the power to unilaterally stop either project, but his opposition could influence state agencies that need to approve permits for Enbridge. Some environmental groups believe that a new Department of Natural Resources under Walz could restart the environmental review process for PolyMet based on the assertion that the company plans to build a larger mine than proposed. Walz maintains that both projects should move forward if they meet state environmental standards. However, he emphasizes the need for meaningful engagement with tribes affected by the Enbridge project, particularly those opposed to it. The frustration of environmental groups in Minnesota highlights their lack of political influence on these projects and the divide within the DFL between those supporting economic development and those concerned about environmental damage. While environmentalists still support much of Walz's agenda, they will continue to fight against the PolyMet and Enbridge projects through lawsuits, protests, and lobbying. Some environmental groups remain hopeful about the potential for the Walz administration to promote sustainable and clean economic growth, particularly due to Lt. Gov. Peggy Flanagan's opposition to Enbridge.
label: true
explanation: Minnesota’s most influential environmental organizations are often politically aligned with the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party. But many of those groups aren’t feeling particularly victorious after the DFL’s big victories earlier this month.

claim: Dutch woman aged 107 survives coronavirus.
summarized_text: Cornelia Ras fell ill on March 17, the day after her 107th birthday, Dutch newspaper AD reported, after attending a church service with other residents of her nursing home on Goeree-Overflakkee, an island in the southwest of the country. She and 40 others at the service were subsequently diagnosed as carrying the virus. Twelve of that group have since died, but Ras was told by her doctors on Monday that she had beaten the infection. “We did not expect her to survive this”, her niece Maaike de Groot told the newspaper. “She takes no medicines, still walks well and gets down on her knees every night to thank the Lord. From the looks of it, she will be able to continue to do so.” Prior to Ras, the oldest widely documented coronavirus survivor was Bill Lapschies, a 104-year-old American.
label: true
explanation: A 107-year old Dutch woman has recovered from the coronavirus, probably becoming the oldest survivor of the pandemic in the world.

From the looks of it, she will be able to continue to do so.”     Prior to Ras, the oldest widely documented coronavirus survivor was Bill Lapschies, a 104-year-old American.

claim: Blood-Pressure Drugs Linked to Birth Defects
summarized_text: A recent study published in the New England Journal of Medicine has found that the use of ACE inhibitors, a class of blood-pressure drugs, during the first trimester of pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of birth defects. The study analyzed data from over 465,000 infants born between 1995 and 2008, and found that the rate of birth defects was nearly tripled in women who had taken ACE inhibitors during the first trimester. The article highlights the risks of using ACE inhibitors during pregnancy, specifically in the first trimester. It mentions that the study did not quantify the possible benefits to the mother for using this drug during pregnancy, but emphasizes that the harms to the fetus are clearly mentioned. However, it fails to mention the risks of not using ACE inhibitors in certain populations, such as women with congestive heart failure or diabetes. The article also discusses the impact of pregnancy on blood pressure, stating that it can either lower or raise blood pressure in women. It notes that ACE inhibitors have been commonly prescribed since the early 1980s and have been used by pregnant women, although the number of women taking them early in pregnancy is unknown but likely small. The story presents the rate of birth defects for women not taking blood pressure medication as 2.6%, while the actual data from the journal article reports a rate of 1.98%. Similarly, the article states that the rate of birth defects for women taking ACE inhibitors during the first trimester is 7.1%, whereas the journal article reports a rate of 8.6%. The article fails to mention that the data only pertains to birth defects after ACE inhibitor use during the first trimester. The article includes a list of other medications that can be used to lower blood pressure, but notes that these medications also lack clinical testing for safety in pregnant women. It references the original retrospective study and provides information on where it can be found. The sources of information for the article include the journal article, an author of the study, and spokespersons from the FDA and its Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. Overall, the article focuses on the risks associated with using ACE inhibitors during pregnancy, but fails to provide a cost comparison with other medications or quantify the potential benefits to the mother. It also inaccurately presents the rates of birth defects for women not taking blood pressure medication and those taking ACE inhibitors during the first trimester.
label: true
explanation: This article reports recent research results that indicate that the use of popular high blood pressure drugs called ACE inhibitors may, during the first trimester of pregnancy, increase the rate of birth defects from 2.6 per 100 to 7.1 per 100. Although ACE inhibitors have been used for 25 years, the potential risk to human fetuses during the first third of pregnancy had not been explicitly studied. The article would have been improved if it had included the fact that there may also be risks associated with not using ACE inhibitors for some women, such as those with congestive heart failure or diabetes. Overall, this story was very well written and reported.
summarized_main_text:
A recent study published in the New England Journal of Medicine has found that the use of ACE inhibitors, a class of blood-pressure drugs, during the first trimester of pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of birth defects. The study analyzed data from over 465,000 infants born between 1995 and 2008, and found that the rate of birth defects was nearly tripled in women who had taken ACE inhibitors during the first trimester.

The article highlights the risks of using ACE inhibitors during pregnancy, specifically in the first trimester. claim: A new Facebook feature enabling users to report problems by shaking their phones has caused some users to be inadvertently reported for abuse and suspended.
summarized_text: Facebook has introduced a new feature in their mobile app called "shake-to-report" which allows users to report problems by shaking their phones. However, some users have reported that this feature has inadvertently led to their accounts being suspended. The issue gained attention when a viral Facebook post warned users about the potential consequences of using the feature. The post advised users to turn off the "shake-to-report" button to avoid landing in "Facebook jail" (having their accounts suspended). The "shake-to-report" feature was rolled out by Facebook in late May 2019. It allows users to easily report bugs or technical issues by shaking their phones, which brings up a pop-up menu to file a report. Previously, this feature was available as an opt-in feature on iOS, but it will soon become a default setting on both iOS and Android. Facebook confirmed that the "shake-to-report" feature is enabled by default and can be accessed by shaking the phone or through the Help & Support menu in the app. However, it is important to note that the feature does not automatically send a report to Facebook. Instead, it provides a link to a report form where users can explain the problem. This means that reports cannot be sent accidentally. Furthermore, the feature is specifically designed to report technical issues and bugs, not abusive posts or other violations of Facebook's terms of service. Instructions for reporting abuse can be found on Facebook's help page. In summary, the "shake-to-report" feature is real and automatically enabled if it has been rolled out to a user's app. However, it is not possible to inadvertently send reports or suspend someone's account by using the feature. Users have the option to disable the feature by shaking their phone or accessing the Help & Support menu.
label: false
explanation: What's true: Facebook has begun rolling out a 'shake-to-report' feature in their mobile app. What's false: The feature does not collect reports about abusive posts or other terms-of-service violations and cannot accidentally trigger account suspensions.

claim: Merck Says Thousands File for Vioxx Payments.
summarized_text: Merck has announced that thousands of people have filed for payments in the program to resolve heart attack and stroke claims related to their arthritis pill, Vioxx. The company withdrew Vioxx from the market in 2004 after research showed that it doubled the risk of heart attack and stroke in patients who took it for at least 18 months. Over 20 million people in the United States had used the drug, resulting in tens of thousands of personal-injury lawsuits against Merck. According to Merck, out of the 47,000 people who registered eligible injuries, about 44,000 have submitted the necessary documents to qualify for an interim payment. These payments are part of a settlement agreement reached in November, which requires Merck to meet an 85 percent threshold for receiving enrollment documents in various claims categories. If this threshold is met, Merck will be obligated to pay $4.85 billion in installments into a resolution fund. Merck stated that 5,500 eligible claimants alleging death from heart attack and stroke have initiated enrollment, along with over 26,500 eligible claimants alleging more than 12 months of use. However, the eligibility of another 5,000 claimants who have sought to enroll still needs to be determined. Despite this, Merck expects to meet all enrollment thresholds. To cover the cost of the settlement agreement, Merck recorded a pretax charge of $4.85 billion in the fourth quarter of 2007. The company's shares were trading slightly lower at $44.23 on the New York Stock Exchange. In summary, thousands of people have filed for payments in the program to resolve heart attack and stroke claims related to Merck's arthritis pill, Vioxx. Merck expects to meet all enrollment thresholds and pay $4.85 billion in installments into a resolution fund as part of the settlement agreement.
label: true
explanation: Merck & Co (MRK.N) on Monday said it has moved closer to resolving thousands of claims arising from its 2004 withdrawal of arthritis pill Vioxx, with 93 percent of people alleging the drug caused a heart attack or stroke submitting documents in a $4.85 billion settlement.
summarized_main_text:

The company withdrew Vioxx from the market in 2004 after research showed that it doubled the risk of heart attack and stroke in patients who took it for at least 18 months. Over 20 million people in the United States had used the drug, resulting in tens of thousands of personal-injury lawsuits against Merck.

According to Merck, out of the 47,000 people who registered eligible injuries, about 44,000 have submitted the necessary documents to qualify for an interim payment. These payments are part of a settlement agreement reached in November, which requires Merck to meet an 85 percent threshold for receiving enrollment documents in various claims categories. If this threshold is met, Merck will be obligated to pay $4.85 billion in installments into a resolution fund.

Merck stated that 5,500 eligible claimants alleging death from heart attack and stroke have initiated enrollment, along with over 26,500 eligible claimants alleging more than 12 months of use. However, the eligibility of another 5,000 claimants who have sought to enroll still needs to be determined. Despite this, Merck expects to meet all enrollment thresholds.

To cover the cost of the settlement agreement, Merck recorded a pretax charge of $4.85 billion in the fourth quarter of 2007. The company's shares were trading slightly lower at $44.23 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Merck expects to meet all enrollment thresholds and pay $4.85 billion in installments into a resolution fund as part of the settlement agreement.

claim: For kids’ coughs, silence is golden and sweet
summarized_text: Other than to describe honey as "cheap" the story does not discuss costs. However, because honey is a food product, prices are dependent on the store and source. The story does not quantify the benefits of honey. By how much did the children cough less and sleep better? Did this result in a shorter duration of symptoms? The story explains that honey may cause an allergic reaction and that, rarely, it contains bacteria. The story adequately describes the design of the current study. The story does not exaggerate the prevalence of common colds. The story does quote an independent expert in addition to the lead author of the study. The story mentions cough medicine as the alternative. Clearly honey and over-the-counter cough medicine are available. The story mentions that using honey as a treatment is not a new idea. There is no way to know if the story relied on a press release as the sole source of information.
label: true
explanation: This story reports on the publication of a study in this week’s Journal of the American Medical Association comparing honey to cough syrup or no treatment for upper respiratory infections in children ages 2 to 18. The study found a modest benefit to honey over no treatment and no difference between honey and cough medicine. The study is timely because of recent news about the potential harms of over-the-counter cough and cold preparations for younger children. It is also "cold and flu season", and many parents are no doubt grappling with ways to provide symptom relief. claim: Singer Dolly Parton donated USD$1 million toward research into treatments against COVID-19.
summarized_text: Country music icon Dolly Parton donated $1 million towards research for antibody treatment against COVID-19. She made the announcement on her Instagram account on April 1, 2020, stating that the donation would go to researchers at Vanderbilt University. Parton mentioned Dr. Naji Abumrad, a professor of surgery at the university's medical center, as a longtime friend who informed her about the bridge treatment they had developed to save lives while waiting for a vaccine. Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC) confirmed the donation and explained that their researchers were conducting urgent clinical trials on existing drugs to reduce life-threatening symptoms associated with COVID-19. They were also focusing on developing new therapies to effectively treat and prevent the infection. The goal was to provide a bridge for those infected until a safe and effective vaccine could be developed, which was projected to take 12-18 months. Jeff Balser, MD, PhD, President and CEO of VUMC and Dean of the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, expressed gratitude for Parton's generosity and stated that the funds would support promising research that could benefit millions in their battle against the virus. The news of Parton's involvement in COVID-19 treatment research gained attention on Twitter when journalist Yashar Ali shared a link to a story about vaccine and treatment research, mentioning Parton's name. This tweet was then shared by Ian Hartshorn, a professor at the University of Nevada-Reno, who highlighted Parton's significant contribution compared to other celebrities who had only sung songs on their phones. The article also mentions Parton's involvement with the Buffy The Vampire Slayer franchise. Parton, along with her former manager Sandy Gallin, founded Sandollar Productions, the company that produced both the original Buffy movie and its television adaptation. Although Parton was not mentioned in the end credits, the character Buffy Summers was given Parton's birthday, January 19. In summary, Dolly Parton donated $1 million towards research for COVID-19 treatments at Vanderbilt University. The funds would support urgent clinical trials on existing drugs and the development of new therapies. Parton's involvement gained attention on Twitter, and the article also mentions her connection to the Buffy The Vampire Slayer franchise.
label: true

claim: Suicide among veterans highest in western US, rural areas.
summarized_text: According to the first-ever Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) data on suicide by state, Montana, Utah, Nevada, and New Mexico have the highest rates of veteran suicide as of 2014. These states have suicide rates of 60 per 100,000 individuals or higher, far above the national veteran suicide rate of 38.4. The suicide rate in the West as a whole is 45.5, while all other regions of the country have rates below the national rate. Other states with high veteran suicide rates, such as West Virginia, Oklahoma, and Kentucky, have higher levels of prescription drug use, including opioids. A VA study found that veterans who received the highest doses of opioid painkillers were more than twice as likely to die by suicide compared to those receiving the lowest doses. The latest VA data also revealed demographic differences, with women veterans having a suicide rate 2.5 times higher than female civilians, and the risk among male veterans being 19 percent higher compared to male civilians. Older veterans make up the majority of military suicides, with approximately 65 percent being age 50 or older. The report suggests that the higher suicide rate among veterans in every state may be due to unique problems faced by former service members, such as social isolation, limited healthcare access, gun ownership, and opioid addiction. The dataset offers more detailed breakdowns on national figures released last year, which found that 20 veterans a day committed suicide. The VA is examining ways to boost suicide prevention efforts, including providing same-day mental health care, expanding emergency mental care to veterans with other than honorable discharges, boosting the suicide hotline, and expanding telehealth options. Veterans' groups are concerned that the data may raise questions about the VA's push to expand private-sector care, as civilian doctors may not understand the unique challenges faced by veterans. President Donald Trump has made expanding private-sector care and stemming veterans' suicide a priority.
label: true
explanation: Suicide among military veterans is especially high in the western U.S. and rural areas, according to new government data that show wide state-by-state disparities and suggest social isolation, gun ownership and access to health care may be factors.

claim: U.S. states, cities sue to block Trump 'conscience' rule for healthcare workers.
summarized_text: A group of 23 states and municipalities, including New York, California, and Chicago, have filed lawsuits to block a new "conscience" rule for healthcare workers proposed by the Trump administration. The rule, set to take effect on July 22, would expand protections for healthcare workers who refuse to provide certain medical services based on their religious or moral beliefs. The lawsuits argue that the rule could undermine the ability of states and cities to provide effective healthcare without jeopardizing federal aid and could impede procedures such as sterilizations and assisted suicide. Critics of the rule, including civil rights medical groups, argue that it could deprive certain patients, including gay and transgender individuals, of necessary healthcare. The lawsuits also claim that the rule could prevent hospitals from asking nursing job applicants about their stance on giving measles vaccinations, even during an outbreak. The Trump administration has defended the rule, stating that it gives enforcement tools to existing conscience protection laws and that it was finalized after careful consideration and analysis of public comments. President Trump has made expanding religious liberty a priority, and the proposed rule has received support from anti-abortion activists. The lawsuits are led by Democrats or Democratic-leaning entities and join a long list of lawsuits by Democratic-leaning states and municipalities targeting White House policies under the Trump administration.
label: true
explanation: Two dozen U.S. states and municipalities sued the Trump administration on Tuesday to stop it from enforcing a rule that would make it easier for doctors and nurses to avoid performing abortions on religious or moral grounds.
summarized_main_text: A group of 23 states and municipalities, including New York, California, and Chicago, have filed lawsuits to block a new "conscience" rule for healthcare workers proposed by the Trump administration. The rule, set to take effect on July 22, would expand protections for healthcare workers who refuse to provide certain medical services based on their religious or moral beliefs. The lawsuits argue that the rule could undermine the ability of states and cities to provide effective healthcare without jeopardizing federal aid and could impede procedures such as sterilizations and assisted suicide. Critics of the rule, including civil rights medical groups, argue that it could deprive certain patients, including gay and transgender individuals, of necessary healthcare. The lawsuits also claim that the rule could prevent hospitals from asking nursing job applicants about their stance on giving measles vaccinations, even during an outbreak. The Trump administration has defended the rule, stating that it gives enforcement tools to existing conscience protection laws and that it was finalized after careful consideration and analysis of public comments. President Trump has made expanding religious liberty a priority, and the proposed rule has received support from anti-abortion activists. The lawsuits are led by Democrats or Democratic-leaning entities and join a long list of lawsuits by Democratic-leaning states and municipalities targeting White House policies under the Trump administration.

The claim veracity: true

Whitman County in Eastern Washington has been given the OK to take a faster path to reopening businesses, including restaurants, under Gov. Jay Inslee’s coronavirus recovery plan.

claim: Blood test for Alzheimer’s
summarized_text: The article discusses a segment on a broadcast about a blood test for Alzheimer's disease. The segment highlights the potential benefits and limitations of the test. It mentions that the test is 90% accurate in identifying or predicting Alzheimer's, but fails to provide context by not discussing the small size of the study groups. The segment also does not mention that the publication in the journal Nature Medicine was a letter, which raises questions about peer review. The report does not exaggerate the effects or risks of Alzheimer's and does not oversell the potential benefits of existing treatments. However, it fails to disclose conflicts of interest, as four of the authors have commercial ties to the company that developed the test. The person-on-the-street interviews do not provide valuable sources, as they are not well-informed enough to have a meaningful opinion. The segment also fails to mention that spinal taps and imaging devices are currently being used for diagnosis. It suggests that the test is not currently available, but implies novelty early on in the segment. Overall, the article criticizes the segment for not providing important information and for not including perspectives from Alzheimer's clinicians or caregivers.
label: mixture
explanation: This report fairly describes a promising but not imminent blood test that may be able to identify people with Alzheimer’s disease. It does a good job, particularly in a broadcast piece, of describing how the study was conducted and its potential implications. The story could have been significantly stronger, however. The report should have indicated how small the groups were, so people could appreciate the potential fragility of these findings. The report failed to disclose vital information about conflicts of interest that was easily available. The person-on-the-street interviews contribute nothing of value, but they consume valuable seconds which could have been devoted to the two areas mentioned above–or to providing insight from a clinician. The ABC News website has a much more complete report on the study. The broadcast segment should have referred viewers to it.
